svg.content: <mxfile host="Electron" modified="2020-03-31T10:30:13.381Z" agent="Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_12_6) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) draw.io/12.6.5 Chrome/80.0.3987.86 Electron/8.0.0 Safari/537.36" etag="Ztk-2w4DMS504UUwh-S_" version="12.6.5" type="device"><diagram id="LQBaBADTUmdg7iCwfanJ" name="Page-1"></diagram></mxfile>

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 38px; height: 1px; padding-top: 271px; margin-left: 46px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 38px; height: 1px; padding-top: 271px; margin-left: 166px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 468px; height: 1px; padding-top: 512px; margin-left: 516px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
With outward growth from the origin of two different shapes, we can model an oversimplified version of the idea of government, where the boundary is limits from regulation.
Resources are evenly distributed in the circle as all growth is equivalent in speed, varying in direction, and is enforced by a circular boundary or is enforced in the inputs by hard-coding the direction difference & keeping speed constant.
In the square, the regulation leaves gaps between evenly distributed growth and enforcement, so whichever agents get to the gaps first can expand rapidly & take up the exploits, shortcuts, & other loopholes to grow faster or fill the space. This situation produces:
- incentivized corners
- optimal paths to get to the corners first
- ability to replace the growth/shape of other agents that occupy other corners
How do you produce even distribution, from a system with built-in structural exploits in the difference between target behavior and incentivized behavior (reaching corners first)?
1. If you insert variance at points in the optimal paths, you can prevent the agents growing in those directions from reaching the corners first, but that wouldn't create even distribution unless it was carefully regulated.
2. Switching the corner agents' position/resources regularly might create even distribution if it was carefully executed & maintained, so whoever occupies the corners first is always swapped out, so no agent achieves power every time, introducing some randomness to the process. However if optimal path information is stored, they can use those paths to get to the corner again in subsequent attempts. This removes the incentive for faster than average growth, but then the population may not develop the functions to navigate the corner spaces, which are different and may be useful in other contexts. The cost is a possible lack of flexibility, if everyone has the same incentives & other resources. The corner-emerging functions may help with other problems than even distribution, like organization.
Switching their positions in an expected process like rotation would allow them to prepare for the next switch, which might develop other functions required for planning. Agents with planning functionality might be able to see the advantages/disadvantages of the system & communication this information to other entities, so collusion could develop from that functionality.
This system has variation in growth options, because growth is not required, just limited - so that's a built-in source of variance. The full set of resources has to be evenly distributed for this to work, except growth direction (intent), so if growth direction can't be changed for every agent growing from the origin, this may not be a possible matching structure for the government system.
Also once the corners are allowed, the entities that reach corners are capable of using the objects & functions developed there to get other advantages (preventing growth to other corners so they can grow in that corner themselves), or influence the other corner entities (send information about developed functions/objects to other corner entities to trade/share or collude to prevent an unfilled corner from being occupied by a third entity).
This could create a system of checks & balances, but would more likely create collusion or monopolies. How could we create a system of checks & balances in this or a similar structure, in case one corner entity or all of them get too powerful or abuse their power too much?
- change the core functions (rather than growth, the initial function given to all agents is share, distribute, equalize, or communicate)
- change the base (rather than enabling evaluation on the growth metric, evaluate on other metrics like system maintenance, self-sufficiency, incentive alignment between agents, interactivity with other systems, whether the system can deactivate if it's producing too much variance for other systems to handle)
- change the boundary (rather than a shape with corners, should the boundary be another circle, to create equal distribution of interactions on the next interaction layer created by the outer circle)

div.div: 4. Create evenly distributed growth incentives once corner objects & functions develop, then remove both boundaries to execute transforms on developed functions

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 168px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1361px; margin-left: 183px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div: Enable standard transforms to develop, allowing system feedback & updates (like reverse functionality direction to allow feedback between inner & outer layer) - interactions with all boundaries except outer boundary removed would create many system interactions between different sets of developed objects/functions, and without boundaries, these will either standardize to comply with the remaining boundary, or create functionality to subvert the remaining boundary.

a.text: Viewer does not support full SVG 1.1
